title: 104_s1379
content:
The "Fair Debt Collection Practices Amendments Act of 1995" amends the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act to include debts owed to the Federal Government or any State. It also allows debt collectors to communicate with persons other than the attorney to acquire location information or information on the consumer's income, assets, or credit if the attorney refuses to provide such information. SEC. 4. VALIDATION OF DEBTS.

(a) Validation Notice must be sent to the last known address of the consumer or any location where the debt collector believes the consumer is residing.

(b) Validation Notice must include a statement in 12-point type, and the consumer must notify the debt collector in writing if the debt is disputed.

SEC. 5. LEGAL ACTIONS BY DEBT COLLECTORS. SEC. 5. LEGAL ACTIONS BY DEBT COLLECTORS. Amendments to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act include expanding legal actions by debt collectors to include where the obligation was incurred and where the consumer resides or is employed. SEC. 6. CIVIL LIABILITY. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to limit damages for debt collectors who fail to comply with the provisions of the Act. Individual actions can result in liability for actual damages, while class actions can be pursued under specific conditions. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act allows for class actions to be pursued under specific conditions, with recoverable amounts for named plaintiffs and other class members, along with costs and attorney's fees in successful actions to enforce liability. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act allows for class actions with recoverable amounts capped at $500,000 or 1% of the debt collector's net financial worth. Attorney's fees are also recoverable in successful actions. Violation of Rule 11(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure may result in the court awarding the defendant costs of the action and reasonable attorney's fees. In any action under this title, costs include attorney's fees, and if a plaintiff rejects an offer in accordance with Rule 68, they may not recover attorney's fees as provided in the title. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to consider factors like frequency of noncompliance and intent of debt collectors in determining liability. The Bona Fide Error Defense is also modified under the Act. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include a new paragraph regarding violations resulting from approved written communication forms by federal or state agencies. Additionally, a new subsection is added to consider the actions or omissions of debt collectors when determining compliance with the Act. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include a new subsection that considers the effect of debt collectors' actions or omissions on a reasonable person. SEC. 7. RELATION TO STATE LAWS. This section amends the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act to specify that federal law supersedes any state law provisions creating a private right of action for debt collection practices. It clarifies that the Act does not provide a remedy or establish liability for violations of state laws unless they also violate federal requirements.
